page.title: Pronouns - Indefinites
page.introduction: A final type of pronouns is indefinites. In English, these include everybody, everything, everyone, anybody, something, etc. Also, nobody, nothing, none are negative versions of the indefinite pronouns. Note that these are made up of a quantifier determiner (positive or negative) plus an indefinite generic noun, and some languages may not merge them into a single word, as in no one for English.

radioGroup.prompt: Beginning with the positive forms, Does your language have any positive single-word indefinite pronouns?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, like English, at least some of them are merged into indefinite pronouns
No, they are all nominal phrases

form.prompt: Key some examples of the positive indefinite pronouns here:
Key some examples of positive indefinite noun phrases (if any) in your language here:

radioGroup.prompt: Now turning to the negative forms, Does your language have any negative single-word indefinite pronouns?
radioGroup.radio: Yes, like English, at least some of them are merged into negative indefinite pronouns but no negative indefinite nominal phrases since the language does not have any means of negating a nominal phrase
No, they are all nominal phrasesand there are no negative indefinite nominal phrases either since the language does not have any means of negating a nominal phrase

form.prompt: Key some examples of the negative indefinite pronouns here:
Key some examples of negative indefinite noun phrases (if any) in your language here:
form.instruction:
Add the feature negative to the negative indefinite pronouns. The negative quantifier determiners meaning ‘no’ that can be used in a negative indefinite noun phrase should have already been marked with the features negative makeDet in
Quantifiers and QP - No other modifiers. If any were missed, marked them now. We will leave indefinite unspecified.
Add the feature negative to the negative indefinite pronouns. We will leave indefinite unspecified.

Add the feature negative to the negative indefinite pronouns. Any negative special degree elements meaning ‘not’ that can be used in a negative indefinite noun phrase should have already been marked with the proper features in
Quantifiers and QP. If any were missed, marked them now: those written as separate words need the features negative makeDeg modifies_NP; phrasal clitics which attach to the front first word of the nominal phrase need the feature negative_prefix and phrasal clitics which attach to the end of the last word in the nominal phrase need the feature negative_suffix; affixes that attach to the head noun need only the feature negative. We will leave indefinite unspecified.

The negative quantifier determiners meaning ‘no’ that can be used in a negative indefinite noun phrase should have already been marked with the features negative makeDet in
Quantifiers and QP - No other modifiers. If any were missed, marked them now. We will leave indefinite unspecified.

Any negative special degree elements meaning ‘not’ that can be used in a negative indefinite noun phrase should have already been marked with the proper features in
Quantifiers and QP. If any were missed, marked them now: those written as separate words need the features negative makeDeg modifies_NP; phrasal clitics which attach to the front first word of the nominal phrase need the feature negative_prefix and phrasal clitics which attach to the end of the last word in the nominal phrase need the feature negative_suffix; affixes that attach to the head noun need only the feature negative. We will leave indefinite unspecified.
